item.title: Bad Bunny Delivers a Joyful Halftime Show
item.description: The Puerto Rican musician celebrated Latino heritage and performed mostly in Spanish in a show that had become a political flashpoint amid his criticism of ICE.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Loren Elliott for The New York Times

item.title: Ejae, Sombr: 9 Songs We’re Talking About This Week
item.description: Ejae and Sombr chased the Grammys with new releases, and Peter Gabriel began unfurling his next album.
item.dc:creator: Jon Pareles
item.media:credit: Emma McIntyre/Getty Images for the Recording Academy
item.media:description: Ejae, who sings lead on the “KPop Demon Hunters” smash “Golden,” released a solo single.

item.title: Brad Arnold, Rocker Who Fronted 3 Doors Down, Dies at 47
item.description: He wrote the band’s breakout hit, “Kryptonite,” in a high school math class, and would go on to be nominated for three Grammy Awards.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: Brad Arnold, center, performing with 3 Doors Down at the Lincoln Memorial in Washington in 2017, in honor of Donald J. Trump’s first inauguration.

item.title: 5 Super Bowl Halftime Shows That Sparked Controversies
item.description: America’s largest stage has become the locus of a few heated conversations about politics, culture or propriety.
item.dc:creator: Marc Hogan
item.media:description: The term “wardrobe malfunction” entered the public lexicon after the 2004 halftime show.

item.title: Bad Bunny’s Super Bowl Halftime Show: Takeaways and Best Moments
item.description: Popcast’s immediate thoughts after Bad Bunny took the stage for a tribute to his native Puerto Rico.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica, Joe Coscarelli, Sophie Erickson, Kate LoPresti, Andrew Smith, Chris Moore, Pat Gunther and Nick Pitman
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times; Kirby Lee/Imagn Images, via Reuters Connect

item.title: The Child in Bad Bunny’s Halftime Show Was an Actor
item.description: There was much speculation about the boy’s identity. The young actor posted on social media about his experience as part of Bad Bunny’s performance.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan

item.title: What Was the ‘Ocasio 64’ Reference on Bad Bunny’s Super Bowl Look?
item.description: And where did his suit come from? The answers may surprise.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Gallagher
item.media:credit: Loren Elliott for The New York Times
item.media:description: The 64 printed on Bad Bunny’s outfit gave the internet something to talk about.

item.title: Bad Bunny Delivers a Love Letter to Puerto Rico at Super Bowl Halftime
item.description: His performance featured a sugar cane field, a wedding seemingly officiated onstage and a New York-style street scene, along with appearances by Lady Gaga and Ricky Martin.
item.dc:creator: Jon Pareles, Ben Sisario and Lindsay Zoladz
item.media:credit: Loren Elliott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bad Bunny’s halftime set featured a replica of a sugar-cane field and scores of backup dancers.

item.title: Turning Point USA’s Halftime Show Pays Tribute to Charlie Kirk
item.description: Kid Rock was the headliner at the streamed concert pitched as a conservative alternative to Bad Bunny’s main event at the Super Bowl on Sunday night.
item.dc:creator: Marc Tracy
item.media:description: Kid Rock at the Republican National Convention in 2024. He performed Sunday night in an alternative halftime show for Turning Point USA.

item.title: Fred Smith, Who Left Blondie for the Band Television, Dies at 77
item.description: In the ’70s, New York’s bohemia was devoted to hostile yet arty rock. Mr. Smith had two qualities rare in the scene: personal and musical understatement.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub
item.media:description: Fred Smith performing with Television in 1977. He joined the band after leaving Blondie, which he said “was like a boat that was sinking.”

item.title: Green Day Condemns ICE as Part of Super Bowl Festivities
item.description: The band’s frontman, Billie Joe Armstrong, urged Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents to quit their jobs, warning that the Trump administration would inevitably abandon them.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: Billie Joe Armstrong of Green Day performing before the kickoff of the Super Bowl on Sunday.

item.title: Bad Bunny’s Sign Language Interpreter Will Make Super Bowl History, Too
item.description: Puerto Rican Sign Language is not the same as American Sign Language. Celimar Rivera Cosme will uniquely capture the rapper’s slang for the game’s deaf viewers.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan
item.media:description: Celimar Rivera Cosme interpreted for Bad Bunny during his world tour in 2022 and his 31-show residency in San Juan last year. The Super Bowl will be by far her biggest stage.

item.title: Bad Bunny Fans Are Ready for ‘Benito Bowl’
item.description: For some viewers, the Super Bowl game is simply a prelude to a historic halftime show.
item.dc:creator: Sadiba Hasan

item.title: Key Moments on Bad Bunny’s Path to the Super Bowl Halftime Show
item.description: He’s had big hits, won awards, co-starred with Adam Sandler and even came out on top at WrestleMania. Here’s how the 31-year-old star got to music’s biggest stage.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Abrams
item.media:description: Well over 100 million people are expected to watch Bad Bunny perform at the Super Bowl.

item.title: Super Bowl Halftime Is the World’s Biggest Stage. He Designs It.
item.description: From Prince’s giant symbol to Kendrick Lamar’s streetlamps, the set production designer Bruce Rodgers “makes the impossible possible.”
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan
item.media:description: “People are hungry for spectacle and excitement and things they can talk about the next day,” said Bruce Rodgers, who works with the N.F.L. and artists to design the halftime shows.

item.title: Partying With Charli XCX at Sundance After Premiere of ‘The Moment’
item.description: The “Brat” pop star isn’t afraid to lean into her party-girl persona. But moving into film with “The Moment” has given her brand-new perspective.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan and Sinna Nasseri
item.media:description: For most of her career, Charli saw herself as “famous but not quite.”

item.title: Body of Nathan Smith, Lil Jon’s Son, Found in Georgia Pond, Police Say
item.description: Nathan Smith, whose stage name is DJ Young Slade, was reported missing on Tuesday after running out of his home in a community north of Atlanta.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Ziegler
item.media:credit: Kevin Mazur/Getty Images for Pencils of Promise
item.media:description: The rapper Lil Jon, left, with his son, Nathan Smith, in 2018. The police said the body of Mr. Smith was recovered from a pond in Georgia on Friday.

item.title: Bad Bunny’s All-American, All-Spanish, All-Eyes-on-Him Super Bowl Halftime Show
item.description: Amid harsh rhetoric from the White House, the Puerto Rican superstar will take the stage on Sunday promising a message of unity: “The world will dance.”
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario
item.media:credit: Amy Lombard for The New York Times; Erika Santelices/Reuters; Emily Kask for The New York Times;

item.title: Carnegie Hall’s 2026-27 Season: What We Want to Hear
item.description: Highlights include the hall’s first “Ring,” cycles of sonatas by Beethoven and Mozart and a birthday celebration for Steve Reich.
item.media:credit: Byron Smith for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Berlin Philharmonic, which will open Carnegie Hall’s season in October, playing there in 2016.

item.title: ‘DWI: Drinking With Instruments’: Experiments in Tipsy Music Making
item.description: In “DWI: Drinking With Instruments,” musicians played some thorny new music twice: the first sober, the second under the influence.
item.dc:creator: Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim
item.media:credit: Richard Termine for The New York Times
item.media:description: From left, Michiyo Suzuki, Franz Hackl and Todd Rewoldt during “DWI: Drinking With Instruments.”

item.title: Bad Bunny Means a Breakthrough for Puerto Rican Athletes, Too
item.description: Puerto Rican football players are thrilled that Spanish will resound at the Super Bowl. “The stage is bigger than the N.F.L. itself,” one lineman said.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan
item.media:description: More than 100 million viewers in the United States are expected to watch the Puerto Rican rapper Bad Bunny perform during the Super Bowl halftime show on Sunday.

item.title: 10 Composers, 2 Directors, 1 Opera: ‘Complications in Sue’
item.description: Opera Philadelphia’s latest premiere is like an exquisite corpse, with a libretto by Michael R. Jackson and starring Justin Vivian Bond.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli
item.media:credit: Hannah Yoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Justin Vivian Bond, the star of “Complications in Sue,” which premieres at Opera Philadelphia on Wednesday.

item.title: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Impulse! Records
item.description: Listen to our experts’ selections from one of jazz’s great labels, with tracks from Sonny Rollins, Archie Shepp, Gato Barbieri and more.
item.dc:creator: Marcus J. Moore

item.title: Talk Talk’s Experiment ‘Spirit of Eden’ Was a Flop. And a Cult Favorite.
item.description: The English band recorded a year of improvised sessions, then cut-and-pasted them into six songs. The result alienated its label, but enchanted fans for decades.
item.dc:creator: David Peisner
item.media:credit: Fryderyk Gabowicz/picture alliance, via Getty Images
item.media:description: From left: Lee Harris, Mark Hollis and Paul Webb of Talk Talk. Hollis died in 2019, and his bandmates don’t talk about “Spirit of Eden.”

item.title: 7 Great Grammy Winners You Didn’t Hear on TV
item.description: Standouts from the preshow ceremony including Turnstile, I’m With Her, Durand Bernarr and more.
item.dc:creator: Lindsay Zoladz
item.media:credit: Kyle Myles for The New York Times
item.media:description: Turnstile

item.title: Chuck Negron, Hitmaking Singer With Three Dog Night, Dies at 83
item.description: His tenor anchored generational hits like “Joy to the World” and “One” by one of pop music’s commercial powerhouses of the early 1970s.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams and Ali Watkins
item.media:description: Three Dog Night in 1971. From left, Danny Hutton, Chuck Negron and Cory Wells. They were one of the entertainment world’s most bankable acts from 1969 to 1975, turning out 21 Billboard Top 40 singles, including 11 in the Top 10.

item.title: Trump’s Kennedy Center Shutdown Plan Jolts Workers and Performers
item.description: The administration’s announcement to shut the center for a major overhaul led to a swirl of confusion and anxiety among performers and patrons about its future.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney and Julia Jacobs
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The sudden announcement that the Kennedy Center will close for two years, starting in July, has created confusion among workers, performers and ticket holders.

item.title: John Forté, Who Forged a Hip-Hop Redemption Tale, Dies at 50
item.description: He seemed destined for a glittering career, working with the Fugees and solo, and then landed in prison. After his sentence was commuted, he clawed his way back.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams
item.media:description: John Forté in 2010. His rise in the music industry was swift, but his fall came just as quickly, when he was convicted of acting as a middleman in a scheme to transport $1.4 million worth of liquid cocaine.

item.title: Cher’s Luther Vandross Grammys Gaffe Joins a Long List of Award Show Flubs
item.description: “I don’t do this part very well,” the singer said, just before she seemed to award a Grammy to Luther Vandross, who died in 2005. Plenty of celebrities have made similar goofs.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: Cher onstage at the 68th annual Grammy Awards on Sunday in Los Angeles.

item.title: Billy Bass Nelson, Original Bassist for Funkadelic, Dies at 75
item.description: George Clinton, while working as a barber, recruited him. Mr. Nelson went on to name the group and, with his bandmates, to be inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.category: Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum
item.media:description: Billy Bass Nelson, seated at far right, with other members of Funkadelic in 1971.

item.title: Kid Rock to Headline TPUSA Alternate Halftime Show
item.description: Turning Point USA, the advocacy group founded by Charlie Kirk, will present a streamed concert that will go up against Bad Bunny’s performance at the Super Bowl.
item.dc:creator: Marc Tracy
item.media:description: Kid Rock will play at the TPUSA halftime show presented by the conservative group as an alternative to Bad Bunny’s Super Bowl performance.

item.title: Stars Bring ‘ICE OUT’ Pins and Fiery Speeches to a Political Grammys
item.description: Bad Bunny, Billie Eilish and Kehlani made strong statements about immigration on Sunday, while the host Trevor Noah drew President Trump’s ire.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario
item.media:description: “No one is illegal on stolen land,” Billie Eilish said while accepting a Grammy on Sunday.

item.title: At the U.S.-Mexico Border, a Children’s Opera Sings to the Moment
item.description: “Pancho Rabbit and the Coyote,” performed on both sides of the border, offers an allegory about migrants, immigration agents and President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney
item.media:credit: John Francis Peters for The New York Times
item.media:description: Victor Ryan Robertson, center, as Coyote, in Anthony Davis and Allan Havis’s new opera “Pancho Rabbit and the Coyote” at the Teatro de la Casa de la Cultura in Tijuana, Mexico.

item.title: Justin Bieber at the Grammys: A Stripped-Down, Perspective-Shifting Performance
item.description: The pop star stripped down his music and himself for a vulnerable but assured solo performance of “Yukon” on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica
item.media:credit: Kevin Winter/Getty Images for the Recording Academy
item.media:description: Justin Bieber onstage at the Grammy Awards in Los Angeles on Sunday night.

item.title: Best and Worst Moments From the 2026 Grammys
item.description: Addison Rae tapped into 2000s pop energy, Justin Bieber stripped things down and Bad Bunny got choked up at the 68th annual awards.
item.dc:creator: Jon Pareles, Lindsay Zoladz and Joe Coscarelli
item.media:description: Sabrina Carpenter performing “Manchild” early in the ceremony.

item.title: Trump Assails Grammys and Threatens to Sue Trevor Noah Over Epstein Joke
item.description: President Trump declared the awards ceremony “virtually unwatchable” and accused Mr. Noah of defamation over a joke he made that appeared to tie the president to Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens
item.media:description: Trevor Noah onstage during the 68th Annual Grammy Awards in Los Angeles.
